>From: Tyler Streeter <tylerstreeter@...>
>
> > ...unless you were intending to
> > transfer the whole
> > project to a real-world scenario I see eye
> > simulation as unnecessary.
>
>I'm reading the book Evolutionary Robotics right now
>which focuses heavily on using senses robots could
>actually use.  My mind is kind of geared in that
>direction at present.  I guess I would like to leave
>that option (transferring neural nets to real robots)
>open, so I am trying to focus on more realistic
>senses.

Then I would suggest you leave out the joint position sensors I mentioned 
before.  Hopefully muscle contraction sensations and touch sensations and 
joint limit sensors should be enough.

More on kinesthetic sense...

Hold your arms straight out in front of you.  Cross them at the elbows.  Now 
put them palm together and lock the hands together.  Now rotate the hands 
down and back up so that now they are pointing at your face.  Have somebody 
point to a finger without touching it.  Now without taking too long to think 
about it, try to move the finger that they are pointing to.  Usually, you 
will move the wrong one.  You LEARN to get it right.  But initially, you 
move the wrong one.  Indicating that the kinesthetic 'sense' is not direct, 
it is constructed based on other senses.

Another tidbit...they have identified the region where that sense is 
processed.  They can stimulate that region and cause one's sense of body 
position to shift.  Interesting, eh? :)
